historicalContext.significance: Captures Cincinnati at its height as a major Ohio River commercial center during the Civil War, with the Roebling Suspension Bridge towers under construction. Shows the busy steamboat era before completion of the first permanent bridge across the Ohio River at Cincinnati.

verification.source: Historical documentation and Harper's Weekly archives

description: Historic 1862 wood engraving from Harper's Weekly showing a panoramic view of Cincinnati's riverfront as seen from Covington, Kentucky. The illustration captures the 'Queen City of the West' during its Civil War-era commercial peak, featuring the busy Public Landing with numerous steamboats, the growing downtown skyline, and the partially constructed towers of John A. Roebling's suspension bridge. This view represents Cincinnati when it was the sixth-largest city in the United States and a major commercial hub on the Ohio River, before the completion of the first permanent bridge would forever change river traffic patterns.
